Problem:
Consider a physical system governed by the wave equation in a one-dimensional domain, defined as \\( \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial t^2} = c^2 \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} \\), where \\( u(x,t) \\) describes the displacement at position \\( x \\) and time \\( t \\), and \\( c \\) is the wave speed. We explore the effect of applying the Fourier transform to the initial conditions.

If an intervention changes the wave speed \\( c \\) to a new value at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the Fourier-transformed state \\( \\hat{u}(k,T) \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\) be independent of the original wave speed?
Explanation: Changing the wave speed alters the rate of propagation of each frequency component in the wave equation. The final state \\( \\hat{u}(k,T) \\) depends on both the original and the new wave speeds, as these influence the cumulative phase and amplitude changes in the Fourier domain.
